description: From Middle English upbreyden, from Old English upbreġdan, equivalent to up- +‎ braid. Compare English umbraid (“to upbraid”), Icelandic bregða (“to draw, brandish, braid, deviate from, change, break off, upbraid”). See up, and braid (transitive).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The act of reproaching; scorn; disdain.
examples: He was ymet; who with uncomely ShameGan him salute, and foul upbraid with faulty Blame.

verbs.description: upbraid (third-person singular simple present upbraids, present participle upbraiding, simple past and past participle upbraided)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic, followed by with or for, and formerly of before the object) To charge with something wrong or disgraceful; to reproach

examples: There also was that mighty monarch laid, Low under all, yet above all in pride; That name of native fire did foul upbraid, And would, as Ammon's son, be magnify'd.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, followed by "to" before the object) To object or urge as a matter of reproach
(UK dialectal, Northern England, archaic) To vomit; retch.
